arm_group.description: Skin ulcers. No intervention. Subjects will be followed up by their respective primary providers.

biospec_descr.textblock: dental broach samples in lysis buffer

brief_summary.textblock:
This study is a single-site trial assessing the specificity of CL Detect™ Rapid Test versus
      the gold standard for Leishmania diagnosis in the US which is microscopic identification of
      Leishmania amastigotes in a stained lesion sample. Subjects will be patients who present for
      dermatology consultation with a primarily ulcerated lesion. After informed consent is
      obtained and the subject is screened for eligibility, 2 diagnostic samples will be collected
      from the subject's lesion in the following order: 1) one sample will be obtained with a
      dental broach for use with the CL Detect™ Rapid Test and 2) a second sample will be obtained
      by scraping for use in the microscopic identification of amastigotes. Samples will be
      analyzed by microscopy and CL Detect™ Rapid Test. The CL Detect™ Rapid Test will be
      performed by different operators who are clinical staff members. These staff members,
      blinded to each other's results, will evaluate the samples from each method independently.
      Each of the 150 study subjects will be followed administratively to the point where a
      diagnosis is established (if possible) for their tested lesion, even if that diagnosis is
      not cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL). If a specific diagnosis cannot be determined for a non-CL
      lesion, the investigator will assign a "likely etiology" (eg, infectious, oncological,
      immunological, vascular, or "undetermined/other" origin). Based on the diagnosis determined
      for each lesion, subjects will be referred for appropriate treatment.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of CL Detect™ Rapid Test to Detect Cutaneous Leishmaniasis

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  At least 18 years of age

          -  Subject is able to give written informed consent

          -  Subject has a skin ulcer that satisfies the following criteria for an index lesion:

          -  less than 4 months in age

          -  primarily ulcerative, not purely verrucous or nodular, and does not have clear
             clinical evidence of cellulitis

          -  in a location suitable for collecting samples by dental broach and scraping

          -  In the opinion of the investigator, the subject is capable of understanding and
             complying with the protocol

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Received treatment for leishmaniasis or any treatment to the lesion even if not
             previously diagnosed as leishmaniasis such as azoles, cryotherapy, imiquimod,
             thermotherapy, photodynamic therapy, within 2 months prior to signing the consent
             form, with the exception of mercurochrome

clinical_study.official_title: Pivotal Trials: Evaluation of a Rapid Diagnostic Device, CL Detect™ Rapid Test, for the Diagnosis of Cutaneous Leishmaniasis in the United States

authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

primary_outcome.description: Specificity will be presented for the CL Detect™ Rapid Test device against the reference method (microscopy). Specificity will be calculated as the number of true negatives divided by the sum of the number of true negatives plus the number of false positives times 100%.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: α, type 1 error, calculated as 1-specificity times 100%
β, type 2 error, calculated as 1-sensitivity times 100%

clinical_study.source: U.S. Army Medical Research and Materiel Command

lead_sponsor.agency: U.S. Army Medical Research and Materiel Command

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Prospective
